text: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production induced by <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 in a human NK cell line .

<extra_id_0> Interferon-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is an important immunoregulatory protein produced predominantly by T cells and large granular lymphocytes ( LGL ) in response to different extracellular signals .

In particular , two interleukins ( ILs ) , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 , have been shown to be potent inducers of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression in both T cells and LGL .

Although it has been reported that there are some T cell lines that produce <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in response to <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 stimulation , there has as yet been no report of a natural killer ( NK ) cell line that responds in a similar manner .

In this report we present evidence that the cell line NK3.3 derived from human NK cells , responds to both <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 , as measured by increases in <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) cytoplasmic mRNA and protein expression .

In addition , when used together <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 synergized in the induction of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and this synergy was attributed to an increased accumulation and stability of the <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNAs .

To investigate the signaling pathways involved in the gene induction , five inhibitors , cyclosporin A ( CsA ) , <extra_id_0> transforming growth factor-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , cycloheximide , genistein , and staurosporine A , were used in analyzing the effects of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 on NK3.3 cells .

The results suggest that activation of protein kinase C , but not new protein synthesis , is required for <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cytoplasmic mRNA .

In contrast , IL-12 induction of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cytoplasmic mRNA appears to only partially depend on activation of protein kinase C . Furthermore , both transforming growth factor-beta and genistein , a tyrosine kinase inhibitor , could suppress <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 signaling but CsA was generally inactive .
It also was observed that suppression of cytokine gene expression by these agents was independent of the inhibition of proliferation .

In addition , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but not IL-12 induced nuclear factors NF-kappa B and AP1 , and regulation of the nuclear levels of these two DNA binding protein complexes is correlated with <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression .

These data indicate that <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-12 may have distinct signaling pathways leading to the induction of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GM-CSF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression , and that the NK3.3 cell line may serve as a novel model for dissecting the biochemical and molecular events involved in these pathways .
